After considering your preferences for a documentary, I recommend you check out "Afterlife" (2011) directed by Hideo Takahata. The movie revolves around a heavily neurotic young man who starts seeing his father's ghost. As he helps the spirit cross to the otherworld, something happens that they could never achieve in their common life: they finally understand each other.
The film stars Chris Mulkey, Rosalind Chao, Michelle Krusiec, Mariel Hemingway, Stephen Dorff, Mark Valley, Woody Harrelson, Jürgen Prochnow, etc.

After decades of raising the children, Mrs. Thatcher marries their father. The story is told in a way that keeps the audience engaged and interested in the story.
Overall, both "Lord Jim" (1900) and "Emma" (1815) are excellent movies that you would definitely enjoy watching.

Based on the user's preference cues, I recommend two movies from this list:
1. The Bourne Legacy (2012) - This movie is a sequel to The Bourne Identity (2002) and The Bourne Supremacy (2004). The main character, Jason Bourne, has become a political assassin after being framed for murder by his former training partner, Dr. Martin Black. In this movie, Jason Bourne has returned from hiding to hunt down those responsible for framing him for murder. He teams up with a new ally, a French Formula One driver named Christian Lang. Together, they track down the mastermind behind their frame-up, a brilliant scientist and inventor named Dr. Simon Tam. In a thrilling and edge-of-your-seat climax, Jason Bourne and Christian Lang team up to confront and defeat Dr. Simon Tam and his henchmen in an epic battle of wits and wills. With its fast-paced and action-packed storyline, thrilling and edge-of-your-seat climax, intense and emotional character development, and overall excellence, The Bourne Legacy (2012) is a highly recommended movie for anyone who enjoys exciting and action-packed movies with intense and emotional character development.

I would highly recommend "Holes" (2005) directed by David Siegel and starring Miley Cyrus, Dakota Fanning, and Patrick Stansbury as Mr. D.
The movie follows the story of a group of teenagers who are sent to Camp Green Lake as punishment for their misdeeds in school.
At Camp Green Lake, the teenagers become engaged in various activities such as swimming, boating, fishing, hiking, etc.
As time passes, the teenagers begin to realize that they have been subjected to various forms of psychological manipulation and mind control at Camp Green Lake.
In the end, the teenagers learn valuable lessons about the dangers of psychological manipulation and mind control, and the importance of standing up for oneself against such threats.

- Title: Mama (2013)  | Plot: Ever since surviving a domestic violence attack, Kim Addison has found the courage to take matters into her own hands. After learning MMA training in order to learn self-defense, Kim found the confidence to become a trainer herself. She has since set out to help others who have been victims of bullying and abuse just like her. Kim' s personal mission is to empower, inspire and train women and children so they too can stand up for themselves against bullying. Among her students is 13- year- old Logan Chauvin. Logan was terrorized daily in school by callous bullies. He has been training vigorously with Kim to overcome his experience and is now getting ready for his first real MMA fight. Although Kim has done everything in her power to train Logan to stand up to bullies at school, there is very little she can do to protect him from his first real MMA opponent.

conversation.text:
I would recommend "The Taming of the Shrew" and "Her". "The Taming of the Shrew" is a classic Shakespearean play that tells the story of how Petruchio, an incredibly lusty man from Verona, seduces Katherine, the youngest daughter of Baptista, the richest man in Padua. The movie version of this play, directed by David Fincher and starring Jennifer Lawrence as Katherine and Adam Driver as Petruchio, has received widespread critical acclaim and is widely considered to be one of the best movies ever made. "Her" is another classic Shakespearean play that tells the story of how Miranda, a beautiful young woman from Verona, falls in love with her tutor, Alonso, who happens to be Miranda's brother-in-law. The movie version of this play, directed by Lasse Hallstrom and starring Keira Knightley as Miranda and Tom Hiddleston as Alonso, has received widespread critical acclaim and is widely considered to be one of the best movies ever made.
In summary, I would recommend "The Taming of the Shrew" and "Her".
